thread.title: Watch: Ravindra Jadeja teases Aussie captain Steve Smith with hilarious impersonation | Zee News
thread.title_full: Watch: Ravindra Jadeja teases Aussie captain Steve Smith with hilarious impersonation | Zee News

title: Watch: Ravindra Jadeja teases Aussie captain Steve Smith with hilarious impersonation | Zee News
text:
Follow @ZeeNewsSports 
New Delhi: The Virat Kohli-led Indian team endured a frustrating Day 2 in their first Test against Australia in Pune, with the visitors posting challenges after challenges, both with the bat and bowl. 
India started the day on a positive note after Ravichandran Ashwin removed Mitchell Starc early, as a result, the visitors were bowled out for 260. 
(IND vs AUS, 1st Test, Day 2 - Scorecard | Report | As it happened ) 
However, Indian batsmen, including Virat Kohli, struggled against the Aussie bowlers, bringing an unexpected end to their first innings after being bundled for just 105. MUST READ IND vs AUS: Twitter erupts with jokes seeing India's incredible collapse and Virat Kohli's rare duck 
Steve Smith and Co. came out to bat for the 2nd time in the day and by stumps they were 143/4, with the skipper standing solid at 59 not out. 
Smith, who was expected to struggle against Indian spin duo of Ravindra Jadeja and Ravichandran Ashwin despite being one of the better Aussie players of spin, amused Jadeja in the 2nd innings and the Indian spinner couldn't hold himself from impersonating the Australian batsman. 
Here's a video of the incident:- 
Indian team coach Anil Kumble also gave his views on the Men in Blue's performance on Day 2. 
"I think he bowled steady. He bowled consistently in good areas. Like I mentioned, there were a couple of soft dismissals, and that pushed us back. It was one of those days where we saw Jadeja bowl in the last session where probably every over he was beating the bat three times. It was one of those days where on another day, that could have all taken the edge." 
Second day was was overly dramatic for India, as Steve O’Keefe pinned India down on to the mat with his career best 6 for 35. The spinner was further helped by sharp-Aussie fielders on pitch, who took almost all of the half chances that came their way. 
Australia were 143/4 at the end of Day 2 and lead by 298 runs with six wickets remaining and resume Day 3 with a lead of 298 runs and six wickets in their hand. First Published: Friday, February 24, 2017 - 18:56 More from zeenews
